body: ![img](http://media.giphy.com/media/fpbqdKRPRkd56/giphy.gif)

@mistercrunch I think you're right, we don't need a "to" task. +1 for simplifying further!

Regarding your last point -- when XComs are pulled, there is logic to ignore any duplicate tasks (meaning: same source task, same key, same execution date), so only the most recent XCom is received. Previous XComs are not overwritten and can be accessed by anyone willing to go digging.

Based on your comments here are the changes I propose:
1. when a task pushes an XCom, it doesn't provide a target. Pulling tasks must provide [potentially multiple] sources.
2. by default, `xcom_pull()` has `limit=None` and returns the first matching XCom value. if `limit=N` is passed, then a DataFrame of N XComs is returned.

I'll start working on this.
Very nice. Here's another thought: we might not want to use a SqlAlchemy ForeignKey as the task_instance might not exist yet at the moment the Xcom is created, or set the nullable = True?
Excellent point, I hadn't considered the possibility.
Perfecto, merging!
This looks good structurally. I'm going to get in a deeper round of review now.
@mistercrunch any interest in this pull request? I'm trying to get this working on Heroku so we can use airflow at Heroku. :)
Oh yes oh yes! I'm just a bit behind on code review. Reviewing today
Thank you for the PR btw!

So the reason why it took me a moment to get to this PR is that I was a bit confused.

Are you trying to create your Connection objects from env vars, or do you want to bypass the Connection model altogether? Because from reading the code it doesn't see like it would...

It seems to be about creating a Connection from an env var. Would it be possible to separate specifying the connection params through a URI and an env var? I could see the URI specification to be useful, even if not provided through an environment variable.

Hey if what you are trying to do is bypass storing the `Connection` in the metadata database altogether, you might be able to hijack to `get_connection` method of `BaseHook`. 
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/hooks/base_hook.py#L35

You could look for the existence an env var `PREFIX + conn_id` and if it exists you parse it and return a Connection object without it ever hitting the database. 

That'd be a pretty sweet feature as right now the connection info is stored in plain in the metadata database and many people may want to have another approach.

Thanks for adding this. I'm thinking about change management here and wondering how to approach this to make it easy on the community. What about adding a `is_encrypted` field set to `False` by default and set to `True` upon first save/encryption? 

Also I had spotted this before, but I don't think it's as flexible as your solution since we wouldn't be able to decrypt or not based on the `is_encrypted` field :
http://sqlalchemy-utils.readthedocs.org/en/latest/data_types.html#module-sqlalchemy_utils.types.encrypted

What do you think?
ha. nice warning in the comments. Give me a few moments to rework this.
[This](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/compare/airbnb:master...nave91:add_extra_to_connection_init) can actually solve my problem.
I want to +1 this.
Yeah, I explicitly left out the change management piece because I didn't know the best way to proceed. I'm ok with your approach. Let me fix this up and send it over.

Via PythonOperator and boto you should be able to do such stuff.

Hi,

Regards,
Sarvesh

Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.￼
I just pulled your simple commit in master, there are no good reasons why it wasn't in there....

I went a little overboard here and that's largely due to there not being a way to upgrade the metadata database. If there was a way to do it, it wasn't obvious to me. Plus the `initdb` and `resetdb` commands were using Sqlalchemy's create_all and drop_all functions which didn't account for new migrations. I installed alembic and have a migrations folder to manage changes to the metadata database. Here's the premise of what I changed and assumptions:

If a user already has airflow running, they can issue a new command called `airflow upgradedb` and that will migrate any new database changes that need to happen over time. Running this command will be required when a user upgrades airflow when it has db migrations in the release. This also assumes that from this point forward the user will be on at least version 1.3.0. If the db schema does not include changes up to 1.3.0, the user will be out of luck (maybe we can create a migration file to get people up to speed).

If the user is creating airflow from scratch, all of the migrations and current quickstart guide will run as expected `airflow initdb` and the versioning will be created in the database properly. 

For those wanting to help develop and need to create a database migration the workflow would look something like this:

```
$ pwd
~/airflow
$ cd airflow
$ alembic revision -m "add new field to db"
  Generating ~/airflow/airflow/migrations/versions/12341123_add_new_field_to_db.py
```

From there, the appropriate steps can be taken to do the migration or what ever else needs to be taken care of. 

This pull request kinda went in all sorts of directions. Let me know if this isn't what you were expecting and I can change it.

@mistercrunch just updated:
1. Separated `XCom.get_one` and `XCom.get_many`. `xcom_pull()` calls `get_one()` (potentially multiple times) and removes the need to worry about limits or handling complex returns. Users who really need multiple XComs can call `get_many` directly; if it turns out there's demand we can easily wrap `pull_many` (but let's wait and see).
2. Added "soft" uniqueness by deleting any matching XComs before new ones are `set()`. I don't think a unique constraint works for the reason described above. I think that using `get_one()` eliminates the need to worry about this anyway, since it will always pull the most recent XCom.
3. Had to add back the `expunge_all` and `commit` because it looks like `@providesession` calls `expunge_all` and therefore doesn't allow objects to be added. I didn't want to change the decorator in case that's for a specific reason.

You may want to drop down to troubleshooting pyhs2 directly, looks like the bug may be in that library (or is it in the way to hook is using it?). If you can make pyhs2 work outside of Airflow in your environment then you can easily retrofit the hook to make it work. Unfortunately pyhs2 has gone without a maintainer recently...
https://github.com/BradRuderman/pyhs2

Anybody else using pyhs2 in PLAIN mode? We use NOSASL so i can't really help troubleshooting PLAIN...

I think this is great!

You're addressing overdue things I've been putting off for a while (encryption + alembic). I'm very familiar with Django's "south" module but was putting off alembic for no good reason (mostly putting off having to deal with change management and the scare of me or anyone in the community getting tangled as I used to with Django's south before knowing it well...).

The PR looks solid after a quick scan. I'm out sailing today (Airbnb offsite!), but I'll actually take a backup of our production db hopefully tomorrow and get this running.

I'd be nice to add a piece of code that runs early in the CLI and looks for the alembic version in the code versus the one in the DB and suggests the user to take a backup and run `airflow upgradedb` and exits if the versions don't match. It doesn't have to be part of this PR but it should make the next Pypi release.

Not a bad idea at all but I'm not sure about this one. I'll stick with the idea that "explicit is better than implicit" and keep the common interface to all operators. Also, it's not uncommon to use the same function with different arguments within the same DAG (which in that case you'd be explicit about task_id).

Someone reading your pipeline is most likely unaware of this `PythonOperator` magic and may be confused as to why that one task has no task_id explicitly defined. Magical behaviors are also usually hard to pinpoint in the source (is this PythonOperator magic? BaseOperator magic?). Should I expect this to work in the `PythonBranchOperator`? ...
Fair enough!

I'm doing some work in bolkedebruin/airflow kerberos branch. I'm taking the hue approach - ie a key tab file and tickets that are renewed by a separate process (airflow kerberos). This process will be required wherever airflow is running. I haven't thought about it how to implement in with Celery. Sudo I won't touch as this is something else than Kerberos support. To make use of the Kerberos support the different hooks need to updated.

> On Aug 19, 2015, at 10:35 PM, Maxime Beauchemin notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> Are you using LocalExecutor or CeleryExecutor?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

LocalExecutor spins off a multiprocess pool inside the command. Each `airflow` cli command has its own multiprocess pool. Meaning if your concurrency is set to 10 and you have 10 backfill commands running at once, you'll get 100 tasks running simultaneously.

Also your `ps|grep|wc`combo will always look maxed out as you're looking at the number of processes and I believe they all get created regardless of how they are used.

The proper way to get a shared pool of slots is through the CeleryExecutor.

I tried installing and it looks like I need `libffi-dev` on my debian box to install cryptography. Looks like most crypto library in python require some sort of os dependency so there are no ways around it...

What about making encryption an opt-in feature? (It's really important to me to allow people to `pip install airflow` and get going instantly without having to install non instantaneous packages). You could move the cryptography `import` statement in a `try` block within the `set_password` method and fallback on storing plain if the lib isn't available. This would require a small note in `docs/installation.rst` and a new `extras_require`  group named `cryptography` in `setup.py`

Let me know if this goes beyond your original intent, I can take over the branch.

Discovered a cause. When I run the backfill, celery executor tries to run this command: airflow run example_python_operator print_the_context 2015-08-10T00:00:00  --pickle 6 --local      -s 2015-08-10T00:00:00

The --pickle 6 argument seems to cause the error, no idea what this means but when I leave it out it runs correct. I found out by adding some print statements in the celery_executor.py file if that would help to understand.

Hope this helps to identify the problem.

It could be nice to have some master toggle switch, but it's typically something that never happens here expect when we do major infrastructure migrations and then I'll just kill the scheduler manually.

I don't think sqlite supports any sort of concurrency, I'd be surprised if it worked along with Celery.

Do you have a homogenous configuration (all nodes talking to the same database)? 

The backfill logs the commands it puts on the message queue, to debug you can take that statement, and try to run it on a worker node and it should run properly. All of this should be done while trying to recreate the environmental conditions under which your worker operates (same box, same env vars, same user, ...)

I think this brings up an interesting dichotomy. On one hand, you want to be able to quickly run `pip install airflow` to get started and, on the other, passwords should be stored safely by default. Personally, I lean on the second one, making the product secure by default. Ideally, I'd like to be able to put a Heroku Button on this project, so that if people want to, they could deploy the whole thing with a push of button. 

Anyway, I'm getting off track. As an alternative, would it be ok to put instructions on how to install libffi-dev per OS environment in the airflow instructions because it would a dependency of the project?

Let's get best of both worlds. It's really important to me to be able to get going instantly. Many operators don't require passwords (BashOperator, PythonOperator, HiveOperator, Presto*, ... ), and sometimes people don't have sudo rights on the boxes they need Airflow to work on. If someone simply wants to go through the tutorial I don't want them to spend more time installing software than it takes them to go through the tutorial...

Anyhow, this make it very clear that the passwords are stored in clear, and the steps to take to address it:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/279

I rebased and addressed the coalesce py3 issue

`one_success` may be as clear (or as confusing) as `any_success`, `any` may be implying that it may wait for all parent tasks to be done. Anyhow both names are arguably as confusing, so I'll take the approach or clarifying the docs.

The pickle is the mechanism by which your local DAG gets serialized and shipped to the worker. Pickling is the common term for serializing in Python. 

Airflow attemps to pickle your DAG, ships it to the metadata database and gets an id associated with it. This id is passed around to the workers so that they pick up the pickle, deserialize it and run it.

`unusual_prefix_` is a hack to avoid conflicts in `sys.modules` as Airflow attempts to refresh your DagBag from the underlying changing code.

For now and until I manage to recreate the bug and fix it, I'd say use `--local` when running backfills. Is the scheduler working ok for you?

Funny, I was just looking at this today. As far as I know `ConfigParser` doesn't support env var interpolation; it has to be coded explicitly.

In the past we've used code like this to do a one-time override with env vars during import:

``` python
config = configparser.ConfigParser()

# load config file
config.read_file(airflow_config)

# Check for env vars that overwrite config vars.
# Env vars have the format "airflow_{section}_{key}"
# For example core:sql_alchemy_conn would be overwritten by
# $AIRFLOW_CORE_SQL_ALCHEMY_CONN
for section in config.sections():
    for key, value in config[section].items():
        env = 'AIRFLOW_{s}_{k}'.format(s=section.upper(), k=key.upper())
        if env in os.environ:
            config.set(section, key, os.getenv(env))
```

However, Airflow already uses a custom ConfigParser that checks for default values, so it might be simpler to add the env var check to its `get()` method.
@martingrayson @mistercrunch did this ever get merged? I was about to write one myself but found it here.

I'd approve a PR that does that well. I'm fine env vars having precedence as long as they namespaced in a way that would prevent any collision. There should be an obvious direct mapping with the configuration section and key.

Maybe `AIRFLOW__SECTION__VALUE` (note the double underscores)

@martinxsliu after some conversations with @mistercrunch, I increasingly think that completely dynamic DAGs are outside the scope of Airflow. Too much is premised on the idea that an entire DAG is available for analysis at the time that the DAG is fired. I think allowing DAGs to reconfigure themselves while in flight would require a total rethinking of the architecture. However, there are a couple of possible directions to go: 1. Add dynamics inside an operator. `PythonOperators` can execute arbitrary code with as few or as many "chunks" as required. 2. The `PythonBranchOperator` can implement conditional paths within a DAG, so long as those paths are known in advance. Right now, I think it's mostly useful for "short circuiting" paths that you don't want to run, but once #261 is merged, they will add a lot of versatility. 3. Lastly -- most experimentally -- I'm exploring an idea with a restricted subset of dynamic DAGs in which the tasks are _mostly_ the same but could vary regularly. For example, lets say I have a DAG that has a task for processing each of N files, where N could change day to day (probably becoming N+1). In this case, I know exactly what tasks I'm going to need prior to each time I run my DAG (since I can count the files). So in theory, I _could_ generate the appropriate DAG for every run. In other words, I don't need to by dynamic during the run, only before it. The problem is, Airflow only refreshes DAGs periodically (workers seem to do it more frequently, the web server less, and then only if a scheduler is running). @mistercrunch has commented on this in #116 and #46. So the trick is finding a way to refresh the DAG across the system. One way to do this is to manually expire the DAG when you are finished with it.[1](#fn) This means that the next time a worker/server/process tries to load the DAG, it will refresh it because it sees that the current version is obsolete. But this might be expensive or infeasible with large DAGs. I emphasize that I'm experimenting with this and have not explored any side effects yet. For example, this could potentially introduce/remove tasks and create UI issues. I don't know yet and don't want to go as far as to endorse this -- just sparking conversation. 1: I'm doing this manually right now but it could be an interesting Operator... put it at the end of a DAG... but I have a feeling @mistercrunch doesn't want to make this too easy ;)

Airflow currently thinks of a workflow as a mostly static, or slowly changing DAG of tasks. Different run instances are schedule based on a fixed schedule. 

Having a fixed unit of work over time and a fixed schedule bring a lot of clarity (and some constraints) to workflows. For instance it allows for the Tree, Duration and Landing time views. It also allows for things like looking at resource consumption metadata over time and understand how things are changing.

It's all about how you define your unit of work, and you can pivot into doing things the Airflow way. So say if you receive an unpredictable stream of files, you can pivot into have a task that batches whatever landed in that folder since the last run and label the output based on the schedule. Once you've pivoted to a time based unit of work, things from that point are hourly jobs and align properly. At many companies, pivoting to fixed schedule batch approach happens far upstream in their data pipelines.

Now you could want to instantiate a DAG for each file, and change the workflow based on the content of the file or the nature of the file, that's reasonable and how programmers think in general. 

The static-ish workflow approach is different. Is assumes you already know all the routes that can be taken, and wire the data down the pipes. So if you have 5 types of files that require different processing, maybe you need 5 sub-paths in your workflow that each treat a subset of the files.

But hey, I do see tons of value for "singleton" DAGs that are triggered by events, not all workflows are on a schedule! The whole "analytics as a service" is filled with "run just one time, or run on demand" use cases. I think it makes sense for Airflow to grow into allowing that as a first class use case. It's very easy to hack this together while dynamically generating DAGs (each with different `dag_id`) and forcing a dummy single `start_date` and `end_date`. I'd be curious to see how much mileage you'd get out of this approach. Feel free to give it a spin, all you have to do is to stamp differents DAGs as objects in the global namespace of your pipeline, as in:

```
for i in range(10):
    dag_id = 'my_dynamic_dag_number_' + str(i)
    globals()[dag_id] = DAG(dag_id=dag_id)
```

These 10 DAGs should get discovered as any other would.
Could you just use symlinks to do this? I think you can tell `os.walk` (in the DagBag method) to follow symlinks and that by default it's set to `False`.
Thanks!

Hello @bolkedebruin , I've seen you're doing a good job with the ticket generation. If you manage to create a session ticket for the airflow application I think I can have quite easily a hive operator that uses impersonation by leveraging your tickets.

@txominpelu the session tickets is actually already generated. Ie: you should be able to access hive by the credentials that are now available for the "airflow" user (ie the uid under which "airflow kerberos" is running). 

Impersonation is something else yet (ie. by delegation tickets (preferred) or proxy)

I was thinking about using the impersonation mechanism described in the following gist:

https://gist.github.com/txominpelu/65a85524429e9f4e2c25

That is a proxy user and could work. I would say try it

Just to be sure: because airflow currently uses its own user administration you are basically circumventing the whole kerberos authentication. Preferably airflow integrates with LDAP/AD for its users then you get a little bit of security back. In the end delegation tokens are preferred eventually I would say.

It does seem to work with the --local. Is there a chat where i can pose smaller questions. Airflow keeps on confusing me. When I run for example the other example:  and use this command:
airflow backfill example_branch_operator --local -a -s 2015-08-10; I would expect it to process all sub-items. It never processes branch_d for example. Any idea?
I'm not sure why delegation tokens are safer. Could you explain how delegation tokens would be safer for a example for a job that is scheduled to be run every month?

Because they need the kerberos credentials of the user executing the job? Ie this makes end to end and auditable. Otherwise you are assuming airflow is safe enough to impersonate anyone and airflows documentation states "everything is wide open by default".

This sounds like the perfect use case for the SQL [CheckOperator](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/operators/check_operator.py). Provided you can write your test like this:

```
SELECT 
IF (DATEDIFF(NOW(), update_time) > 1, FALSE, TRUE)
FROM
INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES
where table_name='yourtable'
```

This operator will fail if any result in a row is False. Does this sounds like it would work?

I believe in this case this should work just perfectly, thank you! 

I would still be very interested to find out if there is a way to pull data from a database and then work with it in a downstream PythonOperator. Is this somehow possible?

I believe it is through the very good work of @jlowin. Check out https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/260
XCom is designed for cross task communication. Note that this is only for metadata type things, so pulling in a binary flag, or a couple of values should be fine, exporting entire tables would not be advisable.
